@PieterTobback @Mikwillyj Just to clarify, "integrated equity" is this: every qtr, S&P retains some qty of earnings, i.e., reinvests it instead of paying it out. Add that qty up over index's entire prior history. Divide price by that, adjusting everything for inflation. That's how you get the blue line.

@tills1111 Every quarter, the companies in the S&P generate some earnings that they don't pay out as dividends, and instead reinvest. If you summed up all of those earnings back to inception, and divided the price by that, inflation-adjusting everything, you get the blue line above.

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow If I'm worth $5B, we don't need me to be squatting on Nasdaq shares right now. We need me to be investing that money in the real economy, creating new Nasdaq competitors. If I don't want to do that, then I can hold cash and eat the 2% annual losses.

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow If the only solution is negative real rates, i.e., financial repression, to try to induce people to make real investments at lower returns, fine, but let's put that squeeze on the right people, those w/ sophistication to respond to it, who can easily afford to bear its losses.

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow IMO, there's no question that there are other more powerful factors dwarfing the "High Prices Solves High Prices" phenomenon. Not popular on fintwit, but I'm a secular stagnationist to the core. That is what it is, and it will continue, or get worse over time.

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow Even simpler, use ratio of dividends/investment. Has been rising alongside RISING equity valuations, last 30 yrs. Not even including buybacks, which would make picture worse. (Note: I use gross investment b/c net investment even smaller, but one could challenge the methodology).  https://t.co/fmJ1cRnEhp

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow but debt funding for investment is also cheaper. the cost of both is dropping by the same amount, yet there's increased relative capital recycling (buybacks/divs), reduced relative investment, despite higher existing equity prices.

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow And that's what I think is missing from the discussion: secular stagnation. Lower real returns on new investment than in the past. Can see vividly in the pharma space, tip of innovation spear. Getting harder and harder to solve unsolved medical problems. IRR plunging.  https://t.co/BSWHsrraZB

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow wrt "High Prices Solves High Prices" theory, what needs to equilibriate on the theory is the return on existing assets & the return on new assets (investment). Lowering return on existing assets will not drive new investment if return on new assets also falls, for other reasons.
@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow I don't see why it would mean that, at least not as a cause.
@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow Also, from 1982 legalization to now, rising buybacks/investment ratio alongside rising equity valuations. The opposite of what theory would predict.

@sidprabhu @asymptosis @mark_dow Agreed on antitrust. My issue: we've had very high equity prices for the last 30 yrs, but no sustained investment boom. @Vince_R_Jansen @asymptosis @mark_dow And to be clear, if the real estate or equity is not publicly traded on an exchange at the time of the passage of the bill, then you can hold it forever at no penalty, fully exempt. That eliminates the biggest onerous impact, forcing people to sell non-traded holdings.

@Vince_R_Jansen @asymptosis @mark_dow Thanks. I'd argue it's no more complicated than a normal wealth tax. In fact, can be implemented as a wealth tax. you pay 10% fee on any real estate / equity wealth that is in violation.

@mark_dow @asymptosis Agreed. Piece was perfect, in terms of clearly explaining the point in the best way possible. If you had gone into the weeds unnecessarily, would have confused people & also wouldn't have gotten those kudos for being as quick & efficient as it was.

@asymptosis @mark_dow To address the potential drop in prices it might cause, as wealthy are forced to dump equites over some multi-year period, government could set up sovereign wealth fund to buy the equities at attractive prices, even redistributing holdings across population if desired.

@asymptosis @mark_dow This could be seen as a gentler, "use it or lose it" type alternative to Warren wealth tax. You can keep it, you just have to create new capital, new jobs, etc., otherwise, you hold the economy's cash & lose it to NIRP.

@asymptosis @mark_dow So $5B mgr would be able to own $50MM in existing equity / real estate, plus another 10% of the difference, and rest must be either CASH (eroding @ 2% real under current Fed rate), or you form new capital, build your own asset. Can then hold forever, exempt. "Asset Rationing."

@asymptosis @mark_dow Right now, Fed policy is squeezing all investors equally. Both retiree w/ modest $200K, & $5B HF mgr. If there's an asset shortage, need to put its squeeze onto the $5B HF mgr, on fairness grounds, & also b/c he has access & scale to respond w/ new investment, increasing supply.

@asymptosis @mark_dow Idea is to concentrate the "squeeze" of negative real interest rate policy on high net worth investors who can afford to take its losses, and who also have the sophistication and access to be able to respond to it by forming new capital.

@asymptosis @mark_dow Also, to be generous, any private equity that you are holding at time of passage is included in that exemption. Can hold forever. But any new private equity you purchase, subject to 10% limit.

@asymptosis @mark_dow So, for example, above $50MM, can only hold 10% of portfolio as pre-existing real estate / equity. Rest has to be either cash, or equity that YOU created in the form of paid-in capital (development, initial formation, IPO, etc.). As a rule, that equity, you can hold forever.

@asymptosis @mark_dow In lieu of wealth tax, I would propose the following as a fix: Asset Rationing. Beyond a certain wealth level, restrict the amount of existing real estate and equity a person can hold in portfolio.
@asymptosis @mark_dow Interestingly, Mark's thesis may provide an interesting rationale for some of your proposals wrt redistribution.

@asymptosis @mark_dow Harder to profitably compete against entrenched, concentred, hyper-moated incumbents. Also, fewer low-cost, low-hanging, productivity-enhancing, value-accretive investment opportunities available to be identified/pursued than in the past. Shouldn't be a surprise though.

@asymptosis @mark_dow IMO asset shortage worsened by (1) increased winner-take-all dynamic in US econ and (2) expected stagnation. Solution to asset shortage is that assets get expensive, investors incented to build new ones, raise supply. But that relief valve doesn't seem to be working very well rn.
@asymptosis @mark_dow Just have to note that the term "asset" in "asset shortage" does not include cash. If "asset" includes "cash" then "asset shortage" won't make much sense.
@asymptosis @mark_dow Pt can be framed in language of portfolio preference, but regardless, the point itself, as well as his asset shortage thesis, is correct IMO.

@asymptosis @mark_dow When Zuck goes into fin mkts & buys non-cash assets, buys from other low MPC savers like him. Now they have the money. Financially sophisticated, don't need cash liquidity, go to advisor "Put this $ to work!"-->each $1 more likely to bid on non-cash assets. Dynamic sustained.

@asymptosis @mark_dow Mark's Case B: $1B, all in hands of Zuck--Low MPC, not likely to spend again. Wants a return, not content holding as cash, liquidity. More financially sophisticated, more culturally inclined to go to advisors and say "Let's put this $ to work!" --> bid on duration, esp. equities.
@asymptosis @mark_dow As spending cycle in Mark's Case A continue on, money remains equally distributed, $1 per person, dynamic sustained-->each $1 less likely to bid on non-cash assets.

@asymptosis @mark_dow Mark's Case A: $1B of GDP earned equally among 1B people. $1 per person. Holders have high MPC, inclined to spend again quickly-->more likely to be content holding as cash (liquidity). Also, less financially sophisticated, less inclined to go into fin mkts seeking higher returns.
@asymptosis @mark_dow I don't think Mark is saying any of that.

@glorysk87 the government is guaranteeing to pay you the dividend of the S&P 500 forever. that payout is dynamic and uncertain, contingent on business performance of private corporations.

@LeederOfThePack @HML_Compounder I didn't mention a maturity b/c there is no maturity. And I didn't even say it was a bond. If I stated a maturity, I would have to give you a par value, which would make the security fundamentally disanalagous to the S&P and warp the whole conversation.
@Bobloveshawaii yes, fluctuating w/ S&P 500 dividend.

@ValueHao @quantian1 ...in this case, no reason to fear/anticipate that, since current regs, as written would b more than enough to stop. And if weren't, new rules would b quickly written.  The security is a synthetic exposure to SPX companies. Treasury involvement in that exposure is superficial.

@ValueHao @quantian1 Clearly, exposure here would be an exposure to S&P 500 companies, so a "corporate exposure." Assigned risk-weighting under Basel would be 100%. Even w/o any clarification to accomodate new security, banks would not be able to use it to go YOLO on equities, bypass capital rules.  https://t.co/QaFLKbXlsY

@ValueHao @quantian1 Yes, security issued by U.S. treasury. But coupon value not guaranteed to some constant number. Rather, guaranteed to be equal to SPX dividend. Introduces risk--equal to dividend risk of SPX. Dividend could rise or fall, depending on how things go for businesses.

@ValueHao @quantian1 Suppose I sell you a perpetual that pays $1 a year. You could take the price as high as you want, to infinity, that still wouldn't make the yield negative. Prospect of "guaranteed positive nominal yield" is nothing special here, not a reason to pay premium to original SPX.

@Copernicus2013 no explicit maturity, just like s&p. if s&p gets fully bought out for cash, that's your maturity. if there was a government-guaranteed maturity, i would have to specify a par price/amount, which would significantly affect the answer.

@quantian1 I think the "government guaranteed to be equal to SPX dividend" phrase is throwing you off here. Owning a security w/ such a guarantee is not worth anything extra relative to direct SPX ownership since, trivially, SPX is also guaranteed to pay dividend equal to SPX dividend.

@HML_Compounder @LeederOfThePack So can't be that. I think people r getting tricked by "guaranteed by the government to track dividend of SPX" phrase, treating that as having some kind of special value over and above owning SPX directly. Pro-tip: SPX ALSO guarantees a dividend equal to SPX's dividend!

@HML_Compounder @LeederOfThePack Was thinking maybe some wanted to pay more than SPX bc read scenario to mean security "always pays $56" rather than "always pays *fluctuating* dividend of SPX." But even then, at 3850, the security yields 1.45%, vs 30 yr @ 1.84%. Why add infinite maturity in exch for 40 bps less?

@shishiqiushi also, all assets have a component of price that is like BTC, speculation on what others will pay. Conceivable that wouldn't be as strong as for original SPX. Less familiarity/tendency/confidence to get involved, less attempted buying against gov/owner selling, lower prices, etc.

@shishiqiushi when SPY companies buy back shares, owners of SPY can sell directly into that buying, and can sell at any premium that the buying helps to mechanically create. Owners of the treasury securities don't participate in that same benefit, at least not directly.

Some reasons for discount: (1) Lack of exposure to mechanical price buoyancy of SPX buybacks (2) Lack of QDI treatment (3) Lack of voting rights in companies (4) Self-fulfilling: Weaker market-wide network of confidence in fut price appreciation of this security, relative to SPX.

@walkingonsunsh important to note that buybacks will create the same fundamental accretion for the treasury security as for the original S&P 500 shares. In both cases, continuing shareholders will receive the accretion via higher future dividends per share, because of the shrinking share count.
@steveniweiss B/c the coupon is not guaranteed in any absolute amount. It's whatever the S&P 500 dividend is, and that dividend can drop--sometimes by a lot.

@steveniweiss This is a perpetual, no maturity, so carries risk of loss on ALL time frames. True, there's no risk in the dividend *relative to the S&P 500*--but there's also no risk in S&P's dividend relative to itself. The guarantee here is empty--dividend & its growth are highly uncertain.
@greyrockave there is no redemption. it's a security that pays the S&P 500 dividend. forever.

What the security doesn't get is the mechanical price buoyancy that comes from the literal act of buying back the shares, to the extent that alters trading prices. S&P 500 can sell into that buoyancy, owner of this security can't. So discount deserved, question is, how much?
@steveniweiss guaranteed to track the dividend of the S&P 500. the S&P 500 already offers you that guarantee, i.e., that it will pay a dividend that tracks its own dividend ;-)
@svrnco agreed. And even if it were highly liquid, like a regular treasury, it would lack the price buoyancy that the S&P 500 gets from share buybacks.

Poll: Suppose the U.S. government raised funds w/ a special treasury security that pays a coupon guaranteed to be equal to the aggregate dividend of the S&P 500. Right now, that's ~$14 per quarter, $56 for the year. What price would the treasury security trade at?

Market Cap of Largest 1% of S&P 500 Companies / GDP as of August Peak:  https://t.co/fd5Q6ITAQ7

Exceptions to it are driven primarily by $SPY's float-adjustment. $WMT, for example, is ~50% owned by the Walton family. $SPY owns a ~1% stake in the remaining ~50% that makes up the "float", so it owns a ~0.5% stake in the overall company, shown below.  https://t.co/P6vvQddJbP

The table below shows $SPY's top holdings alongside $SPY's percent ownership of the total outstanding shares of each company. Notice that $SPY owns the same percentage of the outstanding shares of each company, roughly 1%.  https://t.co/TZeEa0BrHy

This point is simple to prove mathematically, but the quickest way to see it is to just look at a popular mcap-weighted ETF--e.g., $SPY. (The example that best captures the overall point of the thread would be a total mkt ETF like $VTI, but $SPY suffices to make the current pt).

@jposhaughnessy @WildmannHans @OSAMResearch @alphaarchitect @choffstein @CliffordAsness @EconomPic @MstarETFUS We can get the returns of buying SPX and selling covered ATM calls from the CBOE Buywrite index $BXM. Here are the returns from June 1986 - June 2018:  https://t.co/dMnzPCHT8Z

@jposhaughnessy @WildmannHans @OSAMResearch @alphaarchitect @choffstein @CliffordAsness @EconomPic @MstarETFUS It's possible to simulate the results using the CBOE indexes. Selling naked ATM calls (and investing the reserve in t-bills) is essentially equivalent to buying SPX and selling covered ATM calls on it, then shorting SPX and investing the proceeds in t-bills, all at the same time.
